results.name: Data Science Warsaw #33

results.description:
On Tuesday, March 20th, we'll have two talks at Data Science Warsaw Meetup (both in English). After the Meetup we invite you to the After Party (powered by NETHONE).

1. "Applications of data science in transport", Paweł Gora

We will explain how new technologies, especially artificial intelligence and data science, may revolutionize the transportation and automotive sector in the near future, e.g., in the field of connected and autonomous vehicles, real-time traffic management and traveller information systems. We will present a few relevant, interesting research projects under development in Poland, e.g., by Aurelis Consulting and CE-Traffic.

Paweł Gora - scientist and entrepreneur, he obtained M.Sc. in Mathematics and Computer Science at the Faculty of Mathematics, Informatics and Mechanics of the University of Warsaw, where currently he is a leader of a research project and is preparing Ph.D thesis focusing on the topic of optimizing complex processes. He is also collaborating as a mentor / advisor / researcher / scientific expert with a few companies, e.g., Aurelis Consulting, CE-Traffic, Letme.ai. His interests include new technologies (especially: Artificial Intelligence) and their applications, e.g., in transport, medicine, bioinformatics and e-commerce. In the past, he completed programming and research internships at Microsoft, Google, CERN and IBM Research, published papers at best transportation and computer science conferences, presented his research at MIT, ETH Zurich, University of Toronto, University of Cambridge, Google Zurich (Tech Talk), TEDxWarsaw. He received many awards for his research, including “Doktoratydla Mazowsza”, “Nowoczesny Uniwersytet”, “LIDER ITS”. He was recognized by the “MIT Technology Review” among 10 “Top Polish Talents” in the “MIT Innovators Under 35” competition, and among 100 emerging technology stars in the Eastern Europe in the “New Europe” competition. He is also representing Poland in the Management Committee of the European COST Action related to automated and connected transport.

2. "TensorTraffic - predicting and optimizing traffic using artificial intelligence", Marcin Możejko

We will talk about the "TensorTraffic" project, in which we are developing machine learning algorithms (e.g., neural networks), aiming to approximate outcomes of vehicular traffic simulations very fast and with a very good accuracy. We will discuss results of our recent research on estimating certainty of predictions aiming to improve our algorithms using methods based on active learning. Out tools may give opportunities to predict traffic in atypical, changing conditions, and design efficient traffic optimization algorithms, e.g., based on evolutionary algorithms and gradient descent.

Marcin Możejko - Machine Learning & Deep Learning Engineer, holds M.Sc. Degree in Mathematics from Faculty of Mathematics, Informatics and Mechanics of the University of Warsaw. He has over 4 years of experience in implementing DL solutions for business. He works in AI Consulting company - Sigmoidal. Previously he worked for Microsoft and PwC.

results.description:
Zapraszamy na Data Science Warsaw meetup we wtorek 17tego kwietnia o godz. 18:15. Spotkamy się na Wydziale MiNI Politechniki Warszawskiej, w sali 107. W programie dwie prezentacje, a potem, od 20:15 Data Science Warsaw AFTER PARTY (powered by NETHONE).

1. Wizualizacja sieci LSTM do klasyfikacji australijskiego języka migowego - Piotr Tempczyk

Dla sieci konwolucyjnych mamy wiele narzędzi pomagającycych zajrzeć do wnętrza sieci i zwizualizować to, czego sieć się nauczyła. Dla sieci rekurencyjnych niestety takich narzędzi jest dużo mniej. Na wykładzie opowiemy o naszej próbie zajrzenie wgłąb sieci LSTM i o wynikach tego eksperymentu. Wykład jest rozwinięciem pracy inżynierskiej Mirosława Bartołda pisanej we współpracy z Ogólnopolskim Instytutem Uczenia Maszynowego (www.opium.sh).
Piotr pierwsze szlify z Data Science zdobywał w spółce Gemius SA, by skrzydła rozwinąć jako doświadczony inżynier uczenia maszynowego w spółce AdPilot pracując nad modelami zakupu reklamy online. W późniejszych latach pracował w DaftCode, a obecnie w Nethone z powodzeniem stosując metody uczenia głębokiego oraz gradient boostingu przy rozwiązywaniu problemów biznesowych klientów spółki. Po pracy prowadzi badania nad uczeniem maszynowym i sztuczną inteligencją oraz wspiera prace dyplomowe w ramach Ogólnopolskiego Instytutu Uczenia Maszynowego (www.opium.sh).

2. “A case-study of CNNs and transfer learning for image quality assessment at Allegro” - Ireneusz Gawlik, Tomasz Bartczak

As allegro.pl marketplace is getting more professional, content quality assessment becomes more and more important. We employed deep learning techniques to ensure proper images quality, pushing offers that fail to fulfil our guidelines further down the search results.
During our talk, we will describe how we approached image quality assessment, starting with classical computer vision based solution and moving later to CNN based transfer learning approach. We will share lots of experience gathered during our journey - regarding dataset building, model training and evaluation, hyperparameters tuning and last but not least, production deployment.

Ireneusz and Tomasz are members of Machine Learning Research team at Allegro. Tomasz has a strong Software Engineering background and made a shift towards the field of Machine Learning in recent years. Ireneusz has several years of experience with machine learning R&D projects in academia and has been developing intelligent algorithms at Allegro for a couple of years. He is also working toward his PhD degree at AGH UST.
Allegro is a biggest e-commerce platform in this part of Europe. With over 80 million active offers and almost 100 million searches a day, it is both most-used local search engine and a truly data driven company.

Razem z Nethone (http://www.nethone.com) - polską firmą dostarczającą zaawansowane rozwiązania antyfraudowe oraz z obszaru Business Intelligence - zapraszamy Was na After Party! Będzie to okazja, żebyśmy w nieformalnych warunkach, przy piwie i przekąskach, mogli zadać więcej pytań prelegentom, podyskutować na interesujące nas tematy związane z Data Science (i nie tylko), czy też po prostu pointegrować się w naszym gronie.
Sponsorem After Party jest Nethone (http://www.nethone.com)

TT: @Nethone_ ( https://twitter.com/Nethone_ ),

results.name: Data Science Warsaw #35

results.description:
On Tuesday, 8th May, we'll have two talks at Data Science Warsaw Meetup (first in Polish, second in English) and then After Party (powered by NETHONE).

18:15
Predykcja cen instrumentów finansowych z użyciem metod deep learning na platformie IBM Data Science Experience, Cezary T. Głowiński

Narzędzi wspomagających analizowanie cen instrumentów finansowych bazujących na analizie fundamentalnej i technicznej jest obecnie bardzo wiele. Natomiast od jakiegoś czasu pojawiają się opracowania dotyczące wykorzystania w tym celu metod maszynowego uczenia. W trakcie wystąpienia zostanie zaprezentowane podejście jakie spróbowaliśmy zastosować do predykcji cen instrumentów finansowych z użyciem metody głębokiego uczenia. Prace te były prowadzone na platformie IBM Data Science Experiense (aka Watson Studio) i o niej też będzie chwilę wspomniane.

Czarek od wielu lat zajmuje się projektowaniem oraz wdrażaniem rozwiązań zaawansowanej analityki i systemów wspomagania podejmowania decyzji dla klientów biznesowych w Polsce i Europie. Jego pasją są autonomiczne systemy analityczne. Obecnie pracuje w IBM zajmując się narzędziami do data science i rozwiązaniami kognitywnymi.

19:00
The Deep Learning Revolution: From Technology to Impact, Chris Rowen

After many years of academic obscurity, deep learning has suddenly become one of the most important and transformative innovations in computing today. Spectacular successes in computer vision, speech and other pattern recognition tasks are capturing the attention of algorithm designers software developers and system architects across many applications. This talk outlines the key ideas of deep learning, explores the systematic improvements in accuracy in perception and recognition tasks, and looks at the rapid changes in underlying computer architectures, in application development methods, and in human-machine interfaces. In order to highlight the impact of deep learning on the electronic world, we trace the technical and market implications of combining low-cost cameras with very smart vision algorithms, even to the point of driving basic shifts on the role of imaging in technology, business and society. These new vision algorithms and computing methods are now spilling over into adjacent areas, especially speech and language processing, triggering rapid innovation and new market opportunities in speech-centric processing as well. At the same time, the proliferation of these smart-but-hard-to-understand algorithms raises important questions about bias and system robustness. Finally, we take a look at how deep learning innovations are flowing around the globe, helping to spur both new academic research and new company formation on six continents.

Chris is a well-known Silicon Valley entrepreneur and technologist, now serving as co-founder and CEO of Babblabs. Most recently, he has led Cognite Ventures, a specialized analysis, investment and advisory company for deep learning start-ups. He has been CTO for Cadence’s IP Group, where he and his team develop new processor and memory for advanced applications in mobile, automotive, infrastructure, deep learning and IoT systems. Chris joined Cadence after its acquisition of Tensilica, the company he founded to develop extensible processors. He led Tensilica as CEO and later, CTO, to become one of the most prolific embedded processor architectures. Before founding Tensilica in 1997, he was VP and GM of the Design Reuse Group at Synopsys. Chris also was a pioneer in developing RISC architecture and helped found MIPS Computer Systems, where he was VP of Microprocessor Development. He holds an MSEE and PhD in electrical engineering from Stanford and a BA in physics from Harvard. He holds more than 40 US and international patents. He was named an IEEE Fellow in 2015 for his work in development of microprocessor technology.

results.name: Data Science Summit 2018

results.description:
On Tuesday, June 12th, there will be two talks at Data Science Warsaw Meetup (both in English). After the Meetup we are happy to invite you to the After Party (powered by MICROSOFT).

Please note that this time we meet at room 329 and not 107.

1. "Solving Image Recognition Problems using Microsoft Cognitive Services and Cognitive Toolkit", Dmitry Soshnikov

In this talk, I will talk about several real-life projects related to image classification or image detection, and how Microsoft technologies helped us to solve those problems. We will cover simple Cognitive Services, which can be used by software developers without any AI background, as well as CNTK neural network framework and neural network training at scale using Azure Batch AI. The talk would be useful for both general software developers as well as data scientists.

Dmitry Soshnikov, a Microsoft technology evangelist, specializes in the field of artificial intelligence, Internet of Things, development of universal Windows applications, .NET platform (F #, Roslyn).
He likes to tell and think on how modern technologies radically transform business and our life as a whole, as well as the unlimited possibilities that technology gives to youth technological entrepreneurship. Personally held several dozen hakatons all over Russia, helped many student start-ups start their projects in various fields. He is an ideological curator of the Imagine Cup student projects competition in Russia. Participated in technological projects on the introduction of modern technologies of AI, chat bots and the Internet of things in a number of companies. Associate Professor, Ph.D., delivered courses and conducts classes at MIPT, HSE and MAI (courses "Functional and logical programming", "Artificial Intelligence").
Author of a number of online courses on the platforms Microsoft Virtual Academy and Intuit.ru, the course "Chat-bots and modern applied artificial intelligence" for Coursera is being prepared for publication. He has more than 60 scientific publications.
Dmitry is a member of the Russian Association of Artificial Intelligence and the F # Software Foundation. In summer, he is the leader of the computer technologies department of the UNIO-R children's camp and Just Dilijan IT. In his spare time he is fond of amateur electronics and make-up, technological magic and digital art, holds Chinese tea ceremonies gu fu cha.

2. "Conversational AI: Handling your user's small talk and conversational chatter using natural language processing models", Alyssa Ong

Ever have issues handling all the random chatter users throw at your bot? Such as "How are you?", "Tell me a joke", "Are you a bot?" Handling all of these is challenging for bot builders but it gives another dimension of personality to your bot and significantly improves the experience. In this session, we will explore different techniques to build and train NLP models to handle freestyle conversation.

Alyssa is a Software Engineer and Evangelist for Conversational AI and Machine Learning based in Microsoft’s Asia Pacific team. Featured in VentureBeat as one of the top 100 people to watch in the chatbot space, she has extensive experience coding with enterprises and startups across Asia and bringing their AI related projects to life. Where majority of developers are fueled by coffee, she is fueled by bubble tea.

After Party!

After talks thanks to Microsoft you are all invited to join us for after party at Znajomi Znajomych (Wilcza Street 58A, 00-679 Warsaw). Vouchers for drinks will be distributed to attendees.

results.name: Data Science Warsaw #38 Przegląd studiów podyplomowych

results.description:
The 39th Data Science Warsaw meetup will take place on Tuesday, August 28.

"Luna: visual programming for Data Science" by Marcin Kostrzewa

Luna (https://luna-lang.org/) is a unique programming language, with two representations: visual and textual. The visual representation is capable of visualizing results on each step of the computation, providing immediate feedback and speeding up the iterative workflow.
In this presentation, we go through the basics of the platform and demonstrate how it can be useful in real life data science workflows.

Marcin Kostrzewa: Luna co-founder and compiler author. Theoretical computer scientist passionate about mathematics, type theory and programming language design. Believes that it’s about time to retire the 70's ways of programming and embarked on a quest to make that happen.
results.name: Data Science Warsaw #39 Luna

results.description:
On Monday, 24th September, we'll have two talks at Data Science Warsaw Meetup and then the After Party powered by NETHONE! This time we would also like to thank Tooploox for help in inviting such great speakers.

1. Augmented reality with Google ARCore, Jacek Komorowski, Ph.D.

Abstract: In this presentation, I’ll talk about the collaboration between Warsaw University of Technology and Google on the development of the Google ARCore (formerly known as Google Tango) augmented reality solution. I’ll explain key elements of an augmented reality solution for mobile devices. How the mobile device tracks its position and orientation relative to the real world? How the virtual content is blended with a real world seen by the phone’s camera? I’ll also discuss some of the problems encountered during the development of an augmented reality solution.

Bio: Jacek Komorowski is an Assistant Professor in the Division of Computer Graphics in the Institute of Computer Science at Warsaw University of Technology. He also works as AI Expert in Sport Algorithmics and Gaming, developing computer vision and machine learning solutions to automate the analysis of sport videos. His Ph. D. focused on face recognition based on 3D face model reconstructed from a series of images. His research interests include computer vision, machine learning and augmented reality.

2. Learning Deep Convolutional Frontends for Visual SLAM, Tomasz Malisiewicz, PhD

Abstract: A broad range of robotics and mixed reality systems are built on top of traditional Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) algorithms. This talk will discuss the frontend/backend distinction in SLAM as well as discuss our group’s recent research on ConvNet-based frontends for Visual SLAM. The talk will focus on Deep Learning architectures for geometric computer vision tasks as well as novel self-supervised methods of training such networks when ground-truth training data is difficult/impossible to obtain.

Bio: Tomasz is a Principal Engineer at Magic Leap, focusing on applied research at the intersection of Deep Learning, SLAM, and Mixed Reality. He obtained his PhD from Carnegie Mellon’s Robotics Institute in 2011 under the supervision of Alexei A. Efros, spent two years as a postdoctoral researcher at MIT CSAIL, and co-founded a small computer vision startup in Boston. Originally from Włocławek, Poland, Tomasz currently lives and works in sunny Mountain View, California.

Talk Keywords: Perception for Mixed Reality, Visual SLAM, Descriptor Learning, Self-Supervised Learning, Fully-convolutional ConvNets, Geometric Deep Learning
Relevant Links:
SuperPoint Research Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/1712.07629
SuperPoint Network Release: https://github.com/MagicLeapResearch/SuperPointPretrainedNetwork

results.description:
On Tuesday, 23rd October, we'll have two talks at Data Science Warsaw Meetup and then the After Party powered by NETHONE!

1. Sales Forecasting Using Time Series Machine Learning - Jérémie Jakubowicz

In this talk we will present the sales forecasting problem and why it’s an important problem for the e-commerce industry. We will review some tools and concept that are key to achieve good results.
Bio: Jérémie Jakubowicz received the MS degree (2004) and the PhD degree (2007) in applied mathematics from the Ecole Normale Supérieure de Cachan. From 2008 to 2011, he was an Assistant Professor at Télécom ParisTech. Since 2011 he has been an Associate Professor with Télécom SudParis and an Associate Researcher with the CNRS. As of 2018, he is in charge of Data Science for the Vente Privée Group.

2. Item-item recommender system: improving serendipity - Adam Szymański

Most of the research on recommender systems is focused on predicting what user would buy which leads to an obvious recommendation like recommending Counter Strike to almost any gamer. I will show a recommender system for Steam computer games that was designed to help users find games they would not see otherwise. Instead of using machine learning presented approach is based on scoring recommendation using heuristic and statistics.
Bio: Adam is a software engineer fascinated by programming, machine learning and inner workings of organizations. Before joining Nethone, Adam worked as a freelancer, indie game developer, gameplay programmer involved in the creation of Witcher 3 in CD Projekt RED, a software engineer at Youtube and Google and as an AI Team leader for G2A. At Nethone, Adam is responsible for managing the direction of technology development and supervising project management processes.

results.name: Data Science Warsaw #41

results.description:
On Tuesday, November 27th, we'll have two talks about autonomous driving at the Data Science Warsaw Meetup and then the After Party powered by NETHONE!

1. Building models for autonomous driving in the Carla simulator. Maciej Dziubiński

We will take a deep dive into the fine art of building machine learning models for driving a virtual car around a race track. For that, we will familiarize ourselves with the Carla simulator (carla.org), the types of input we can collect, and two methods of driving along a predefined path. Based on that, we will build machine learning models for controlling the car, and discuss the caveats hidden in this task.
The overarching goal of this presentation is to introduce the audience to a platform for starting out in the autonomous vehicle world.

Bio: By day, Maciej is a machine learning engineer at Nethone, working on fraud prevention models and other solutions for the business world. And by night, Maciej is a member of OPIUM where he works on autonomous vehicles and other disruptive technologies.

2. Autonomous Racing - from the simulator to a real track. Karol Majek

In this talk, Karol will present lessons learned from two autonomous driving events Self-Racing Cars 2017 and 2018. He participated in the first event in a team supported by the Udacity with an End-to-End network trained in a simulator. In the 2nd event, the team used semantic segmentation and path planning to improve the results.

Bio: Karol Majek is Self-Driving Car and Mobile Robotics Engineer. He successfully participated in several mobile robotics competitions including DARPA VRC, ELROB, Eurathlon, Udacity Challenge, Self-Racing Cars and F1/10. His interests are deep learning (Image analysis; TensorFlow, Keras), mobile robotics (ROS), cloud (mostly GCP). He received a grant in TensorFlow Research Cloud program. He is now working on autonomous cars (Deep Drive PL) and mobile robotics (NASK).

results.description:
The next Data Science Warsaw Meetup will take place on Tuesday, 12th February, and afterward we invite you to the afterparty powered by NETHONE! During the meetup we'll have two talks:

1. Apache Spark on AWS EC2 use case for NLP exercise: Amazon comments mining - Sergiy Tkachuk

In this talk, Sergiy will present how you can leverage power of AWS cloud platform in combination with Apache Spark framework on the example of Amazon comments mining.
As data scientists we are always looking for efficient and cheap ways to prototype and experiment. During the presentation you will learn how to set up the cluster on your own and run Spark tasks using PySpark. You will also see how to set up Jupyter Notebook to communicate with the cluster.

Bio: Sergiy is a Big Data & Advanced Analytics graduate of the Warsaw School of Economics. He works in Schneider Electric as data scientist. He is part of Global Marketing Analytics and AI team and is in charge of global corporate brand analytics. He is passionate about natural language processing and artificial intelligence theory.

2. Understanding neural machinery in text-based processing - Ania Wróblewska, Filip Graliński, Tomasz Stanisławek (Applica.ai)

What is worth to know as a data scientist is not only how to build machine learning models, but also understand their intrinsic mechanisms. We will present a simple but powerful tool to debug the output of supervised models — geval. Geval can give you an insight into what can be improved in the data sets and/or the model.
Moreover, we will present a prototype architecture for automation of processes in text based work and a few use cases for text-based models of various types and explain main findings that are much easier to be discovered using our tool.

Anna Wróblewska Senior Data Scientist at Applica / Assistant Professor at Warsaw University of Technology
Filip Graliński Senior Deep Learning Engineer at Applica / Teaching Assistant at Adam Mickiewicz University
Tomasz Stanisławek Text Mining Consultant at Applica

results.name: Data Science Warsaw #43

results.description:
Kolejne spotkanie Data Science Warsaw odbędzie się we wtorek 12tego marca, o godzinie 18tej, na Wydziale MiNI PW (sala 107). W programie:

1. Kategoryzacja tekstów - Rafał Prońko

Kategoryzacja tekstów ma wiele zastosowań: kategoryzacja ogłoszeń na portalach, kategoryzacja wiadomości, wykrywanie spamu, wykrywanie mowy nienawiści, standaryzacja nazw stanowisk pracy,... W moim wystąpieniu poruszę kwestie kategoryzacji tekstu na przykładzie standaryzacji nazw stanowisk pracy, powiem czemu w ogóle stanowiska, po co standaryzować, jakie podejścia wykorzystałem i do czego taka standaryzacja może być przydatna.

Rafał Prońko - Data Scientist od ponad 5 lat głównie związany z NLP: kategoryzacja ogłoszeń, strukturyzacja tekstu, normalizacja tekstu, lokalizacja, przewidywanie długości pozostania w jednej pracy. Procowałem także nad przetwarzaniem obrazów: rozpoznawaniem twarzy, wykrywaniem spoofingu, wykrywanie zabrudzeń, rozpoznawanie produktów na półkach. Jako Data Scientist pracowałem tez przy projekcie blockchain: tworzenie cryptoeconomy i symulacja zachowań użytkowników.

2. Automatyczne przetwarzanie języka polskiego - z perspektywy organizatorów konkursu PolEval. Łukasz Kobyliński

Ostatnie lata przyniosły szybki rozwój obszaru przetwarzania języka naturalnego (NLP). Stało się tak, między innymi, dzięki postępowi technologicznemu, ilości dostępnych danych i nowym metodom uczenia maszynowego. Wydaje się, że choć w obszarze automatycznego przetwarzania języka polskiego postęp również nastąpił, to nie był on tak szybki, jak w przypadku języka angielskiego. W trakcie tego wystąpienia chciałbym omówić czynniki, które mogły wpłynąć na ten stan rzeczy.

Mając na uwadze te wyzwania, rozpoczęliśmy w 2017 roku organizację konkursu PolEval (http://poleval.pl/). Jest to konkurs skierowany do indywidualnych badaczy oraz zespołów, którego celem jest:
- wypracowanie ustalonych procedur ewaluacji systemów rozwiązujących poszczególne zadania w NLP,
- wytworzenie anotowanych zbiorów danych, które mogą zostać wykorzystane do uczenia i ewaluacji systemów,
- obiektywne porównanie systemów realizujących odpowiednie zadania w zakresie przetwarzania języka naturalnego,
- zbliżenie do siebie badaczy ze środowisk naukowych i biznesowych oraz wymianę wiedzy między nimi,
- popularyzację zagadnień NLP w kontekście języka polskiego.

W trakcie wystąpienia chciałbym też podsumować rezultaty ostatnich dwóch edycji tego konkursu oraz opowiedzieć o perspektywach i możliwościach uczestnictwa w tegorocznej edycji PolEvalu.

Łukasz Kobyliński - Chief Science Officer w Sages, Data Scientist w SigDelta oraz adiunkt w Instytucie Podstaw Informatyki PAN, gdzie prowadzi projekty w Zespole Inżynierii Lingwistycznej. Członek Rady Programowej studiów podyplomowych Big Data realizowanych przez firmę Sages oraz Politechnikę Warszawską oraz opiekun merytoryczny bootcampów Kodołamacz.pl. Od wielu lat zajmuje się analizą danych i uczeniem maszynowym, początkowo w odniesieniu do obrazów, a obecnie w zastosowaniu do przetwarzania języka naturalnego. Szczególnie zainteresowany lingwistyką korpusową, analizą tekstu na poziomie morfoskładniowym i semantycznym, a także efektywnym przetwarzaniem dużych zbiorów danych.

Zachęcamy też do subskrypcji newslettera (https://tinyletter.com/datascience ), w którym informujemy o ciekawych wydarzeniach dotyczących Data Science w Warszawie i Polsce.

results.description:
The next Data Science Warsaw Meetup will take place on Tuesday, 14th May, and afterward we invite you to the informal Networking powered by NETHONE! During the meetup we'll have two talks:

1. „RTB + Algos Introduction” Łukasz Mączewski, Przemek Piotrowski

Real-Time Bidding is a fascinating world like from James Bond movies. Everything takes place between clicking on the link and displaying the page. We have superfast servers, beautiful data and machinations.

2. „RTB Bid Landscape - survival models powered by bitmaps” Łukasz Mączewski, Przemek Piotrowski

The Bid Landscape (BL) is one of the key components of the bidding strategy optimisation in the area of the Real-Time Bidding (RTB). It allows for predicting RTB campaign performance with respect to its targeting and budget settings. The essential element of BL is the ability for predicting auction winning probability for the specific bid price. During presentation, we will go through technological and data science challenges regarding huge data streams we are facing (millions of auctions per second) and right-censored data we are to model (only small fraction of all winning prices is known, for the remaining ones only lower win price boundary is available).

Lukasz Maczewski Senior Data Scientist in DSP Algos team in Research Area. He is an ex-physicist, holding PhD in an experimental, particle physics and a senior data scientist in the Adform research team. In his current role, he is responsible for developing, deploying and maintaining real-time bidding (RTB) algorithms for online advertising. In his former job he was supporting analytics-based maintenance for General Electric turbofan jet engines. His specialization were advanced reliability models and diagnostics algorithms for failure detection. Łukasz has over 10 years of experience in research and widely understood data science.

Przemek Piotrowski Senior Data Engineer@ Adform, AI& Analytics. Responsible for Bid Landscape, Forecasting and Bidding Algorithms pipeline. Contributor to Roaring Bitmaps JVM implementation.

After the meetup we invite you to an informal Networking powered by Nethone. Before the meeting, send questions and problems regarding data science, machine learning or the fight against fraud that you have encountered. Specialists from Nethone will suggest appropriate solutions - they will also indicate the best practices used in working with data. More about Nethone http://www.nethone.com

We also encourage you to subscribe to the newsletter (https://tinyletter.com/datascience), where we inform about interesting events regarding Data Science in Warsaw and in Poland.
